page.title: 03Local Geography
page.content: Much Hadham is a fine example of a roadside settlement. It is a long straggling village lying along the shallow valley of a small stream named the Ash. The valley is about one km wide, and on either side low hills rise, somewhat sharply in places, to a flat stretch of tableland. The stream winds through water meadows, creating some water-cress beds and good pasture. The main road runs North-South straight along the valley linking Ware and Bishop's Stortford, and in bygone days there was a single line railway which followed a similar route through the village, linking Buntingford and St. Margaret's, but this line was closed in the 1960's as part of Dr. Beeching's railway strategy.
